chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Diverticular disease
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with symptomatic diverticular disease in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with diverticular disease?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a person has suspected diverticular disease, but the diagnosis has not been confirmed, arrange a routine referral to a specialist in colorectal surgery to confirm the diagnosis.
    • Specialist investigations may include colonoscopy or computed tomography (CT) colonography to confirm the presence of diverticula.
  • Arrange urgent admission if a person has diverticular disease with significant rectal bleeding (for example, if the person is haemodynamically unstable), as urgent blood transfusion may be required.
  • If a person is symptomatic but does not need admission:
    • Advise on sources of information and support, such as:
      • The gut and liver disease charity Guts UK (website available at gutscharity.org.uk) provides support for patients and families and has a patient information leaflet Information about diverticular disease.
      • The NHS patient information leaflets Diverticular disease and diverticulitis - prevention and Diverticular disease and diverticulitis - treatment.
    • Recommend eating a healthy, balanced diet containing whole grains, fruits, and vegetables.
      • The Association of UK Dietitians has useful Food Fact Sheets on Fibre and Fruit and vegetables - how to get five-a-day.
      • Fibre intake should be increased gradually (to minimize flatulence and bloating) — adults should aim to consume 30 g of fibre per day: Advise the person that the beneficial effects of increasing dietary fibre may take several weeks. Advise that a high-fibre diet should be maintained for life.
      • Public Health England's booklet The Eatwell Guide has patient information on eating a healthy, balanced diet.
    • Recommend drinking an adequate fluid intake with a high-fibre diet, especially if there is a risk of dehydration.
      • The Association of UK Dietitians has a useful Food Fact Sheet on Fluid.
    • Consider prescribing bulk-forming laxatives if a high-fibre diet is insufficient or unacceptable, or if symptoms of constipation or diarrhoea persist.
      • See the section on Bulk-forming laxatives in Prescribing information for more information.
      • See the CKS topic on Constipation for more information on the management of constipation in adults.
    • Advise on the use of analgesia, such as paracetamol as-needed, if the person has ongoing abdominal pain.
      • Advise the person to avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and opioid analgesia (such as codeine) if possible, due to the potential increased risk of diverticular perforation.
  • Arrange to review the person, for example after one month, depending on clinical judgement:
    • Reiterate the importance of a healthy, balanced, high-fibre diet.
    • Encourage weight loss if the person is overweight or obese. See the CKS topic on Obesity for more information.
    • Encourage smoking cessation, if needed. See the CKS topic on Smoking cessation for more information.
    • If there are persistent or refractory symptoms, consider alternative causes for symptoms, and manage appropriately.
  • Consider arranging referral to a specialist in colorectal surgery if there are persistent or refractory symptoms:
    • Despite optimal management in primary care.
    • That cannot be explained by a possible alternative cause.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of diverticular disease are largely based on expert opinion in the consensus documents International, expert-based, consensus statement regarding the management of acute diverticulitis [O'Leary, 2015] and Management of patients with diverticulosis and diverticular disease [Tursi, 2016], expert opinion in the Association of Coloproctology of Great Britain and Ireland (ACPGBI) Commissioning guide: colonic diverticular disease [ACPGBI, 2014], the American Gastroenterological Association (AGA) Institute Technical review on the management of acute diverticulitis [Strate, 2015], a systematic review of high-fibre dietary therapy in diverticular disease [Unlu et al, 2012], a systematic review of diverticular complications with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and other medications [Kvasnovsky, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles on acute diverticulitis [Wilkins, 2013; Morris, 2014; Bugiantella, 2015].

Arranging specialist referral or urgent admission
  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the ACPGBI commissioning guide on people with diverticular disease and rectal bleeding [ACPGBI, 2014], and are pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice.
Advice on increasing dietary fibre
  • The recommendation on increasing dietary fibre is based on limited and conflicting evidence on the benefits for symptom relief and prevention of recurrent episodes of acute diverticulitis [Bugiantella, 2015; Tursi, 2016].
    • A systematic review of three randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and one case-control study found inconsistent results, but concluded that moderate-quality evidence shows a beneficial effect of a high-fibre diet on symptomatic diverticular disease, however the review noted the small sample sizes and subjective nature of the symptom scores used in the analysis [Unlu et al, 2012]. This is supported by expert opinion in review articles which found limited data recommending the use of a high-fibre diet to prevent recurrent diverticular disease [Wilkins, 2013; Morris, 2014].
    • In contrast, expert opinion in a review article states there is no evidence that increased fibre intake reduces the risk of recurrence of acute diverticulitis [Bugiantella, 2015] and an international expert panel of colorectal surgeons in a Delphi study could not reach a consensus regarding the use of a high-fibre diet in the follow-up of people with acute uncomplicated diverticulitis, due to the limited evidence available [O'Leary, 2015].
Advice on analgesia
  • The recommendations on analgesia are extrapolated from conflicting evidence in the literature on the safety of certain analgesics in the management of acute diverticulitis.
    • The AGA Institute technical review states there is uncertainty whether the regular use of aspirin or NSAIDs increases the risk of recurrent diverticulitis, complications, surgery, or abdominal pain, based on very low-quality evidence. It also cites evidence that opiate analgesia may increase the risk of perforated diverticulitis [Strate, 2015].
    • Expert opinion in an international consensus document states that aspirin or NSAIDs may potentially increase the risk of diverticular complications [Tursi, 2016].
    • A systematic review and meta-analysis of pooled data showed significantly increased odds of perforation and abscess formation with the use of NSAIDs and opioids, and increased odds of diverticular bleeding with the use of NSAIDs and aspirin. The review notes that the included observational studies were of variable quality and show an association rather than a definite causal relationship [Kvasnovsky, 2013].
    • Expert opinion in a review article states that there is no evidence that aspirin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or opiate analgesia has a negative effect on the course of an episode of acute diverticulitis, however the administration of NSAIDs at home may increase the risk of complicated diverticulitis [Bugiantella, 2015].
Arranging clinical review
  • Expert opinion in review articles suggests that lifestyle interventions such as weight loss and smoking cessation may reduce the risk of recurrent diverticulitis and reduce the risk of subsequent complications [Wilkins, 2013; Bugiantella, 2015].
Considering specialist referral for persistent or refractory symptoms
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the ACPGBI commissioning guide [ACPGBI, 2014] and is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good medical practice.
